ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES
FOR 1962


    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [6th Allotted Day].

    Resumption of debate on Question (13th December, 1961),

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head D8 be reduced by $100."-(Dato Abdul Humid bin Haji Jumat).

2.33 p.m.

DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES, 1962 (Cont.)


    Head D8-

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday I said that the Government, in the implementation of its policy on the acquisition of land, should pay attention to the livelihood of farmers and people living in the rural areas. In the implementation of its schemes and plans, the Government should not treat the people concerned unfavourably. According to the policy of the Government, the land allocated to farmers is not sufficient. To my knowledge, one family can only get one acre of land from the Government. I can say for sure that it is impossible for a family to make a living from one acre of land. Where can the labourers then go? We know that a serious situation has arisen in Singapore today. All these redundant farmers and labour hands will move into the city, thus aggravating the unemployment problem. Therefore, in the implementation of its policy on the acquisition of land and the resettlement of farmers, the Government should pay attention to the livelihood of the farmers and rural dwellers.

Column: 2140



    Lastly, I hope the Government will reconsider the payment of the rate of compensation. Furthermore, the Government should give sufficient land to the farmers to enable them to make a living.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just a few questions to ask of the Minister concerned regarding resettlement. Could he tell us where these resettlement schemes are and for whom?

    The Prime Minister has said that the Master Plan will be revised and made public very soon. Those who are interested in development would like to know when the Master Plan will be made public so that they could plan ahead. Also, when will the Agricultural Leases Bill be out?

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, we understand Singapore is suffering from an acute shortage of land, but we should not ignore questions relating to the well-being of the people. I think this matter should be quickly resolved. It is imperative that it should be given due consideration, because we are short of land. One important question concerns land on this island which belongs to the Services and which is not put to use at the moment. I think the question arises whether the Government should acquire such land for development purposes. For instance, there are many vacant pieces of land in Blakang Mati. Applications have been received from Pulau Brani, which has no more vacant land, for the erection of dwelling-houses on Blakang Mati. I wonder whether it is possible to make use of land belonging to the Services in Blakang Mati for the erection of dwelling-houses.

    The Government should also give consideration to applications for sites on State land. It is not sufficient for the department concerned to give a reply merely acknowledging receipt of the application saying that it is being considered. This is not very satisfactory. If an application cannot be entertained, the reply should be positive and it should state that the application cannot be considered. The applicant should not be kept in suspense all the time.

Column: 2141



    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, every year millions of dollars are being spent on land acquisition by the Government and yet land hungry farmers still face the problem of a great shortage of land. As far as I know, the Government itself has not much land to distribute to the farmers and the unemployed who want land.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): On a point of elucidation.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan resumed his seat.

    The Prime Minister: It might be of some interest, because this is the first time I have heard that the unemployed want land in Singapore. If it is so, then I will look into the matter. It is something new to me.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, apparently the Prime Minister is out of touch with reality. When I was the Minister for National Development -

    The Prime Minister: Did you give land to the unemployed?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Because there was no land to give. Often there are unemployed people who ask for a piece of land so that they can rear chickens or grow vegetables to tide over their difficulties.

    Now, the Government is faced with a shortage of land. Every year it spends millions of dollars to acquire land from big landlords and other people. It is high time to revise our thinking on the land question in Singapore. Mr Speaker, Sir, in a place like Singapore, where land shortage is acute and the population is growing, this question requires that the thinking of the present Government leaders be reorientated. At present, in my opinion, the most profitable business is land speculation. So long as land speculation is profitable, much of the capital which would otherwise go into commerce or industrialisation would go into land speculation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if we antagonise a small section of the big landlord class, that is, the big land speculators, they are very few in number. If the Government is not prepared to antagonise them, land will never be released. My view is that

Column: 2142

the Government must acquire all lands which are held for speculative purposes and pay for them in bonds. We must achieve our ultimate goal of security of land tenure for all those persons who cultivate the land.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, from what I know, when a farmer is given security of land tenure, the yield goes up. He looks after the land. It is better for the country and in the long-term interests of the land itself. We can pay these land speculators in bonds which will be payable in 30 or 40 years' time, and we can sell land to the farmers on an instalment basis, as in Japan, Pakistan and other places, or we can sell it outright.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in other countries where Right-wing governments are in control, like Japan even during the MacArthur regime, there are more far-reaching land reforms than this so-called socialist Government of Singapore.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, land speculators are a different class from the industrialists. We want to and must protect the industrialists. We want to protect .the people in commerce. But land speculators are parasites; they do nothing but just speculate in land, as it provides a bigger return than if they invest their capital in factories or in business concerns. It is high time the Government did not protect land speculators.

    Sir, besides this land problem, I shall also discuss the treatment of tenants on land acquired by Government. Recently we have trouble in the Toa Payoh scheme. Sir, this, I feel, is due to mishandling by the Government. We also had, in 1959, a resettlement of tenants in places like the Aljunied housing scheme and the Tiong Bahru housing scheme, where we managed to resettle them with the least difficulty and with co-operation from the squatters there. But the Toa Payoh scheme is the first scheme this present P.A.P. leadership is confronted with. We see difficulties and heart-burning on all sides. If we are humanitarian and try to understand the problems of the squatters, for instance, under the Toa Payoh scheme, we will be better able to deal with the situation. As

Column: 2143

far as I know, there is no need to resettle all the squatters at one time under the Toa Payoh scheme. The squatters can be resettled in little batches at a time. We must convince them that they can come forward for negotiations so that we can settle any difficulties.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have always been told that the Master Plan is to be revised. From the progress the Government is showing, I think the Master Plan will not be revised unless and until this Government collapses and a new government takes over.

    The Chairman: Is there a reply from the ministerial bench?

    The Prime Minister: Perhaps a reply will be given in one elucidation to all the points raised.

    The Chairman: If the Prime Minister thinks he has the time.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I do not wish to talk at great length on this amendment. I merely wish to get clarification from the Minister concerned on one or two matters in respect of land, including the area of which I am the representative, that is to say, the Malay Settlement at Jalan Eunos.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to appeal to the Government to enlarge the Malay settlement areas. I think it is a necessity which the Government must undertake. But what I want is a definite assurance in this Assembly - according to the reply given by the Prime Minister in the past - that there is a possibility that allocation of sites will be completed during the course of this year. However, I hope the allocation of vacant sites in Malay settlements could be expedited not only at Kaki Bukit but also at Ayer Gemuroh and Jurong.

    Another point I wish to draw the attention of the Government to is the method of getting State land. For instance, those applicants who submitted their applications during the time of the previous Government paid $25 as deposit. Because these applicants were illiterate, they had complete trust in the staff of

Column: 2144

the department. In the case of my father-in-law, it happened that he paid $25 without a receipt being given for it. Until today it is not possible for him to get a refund of $25. This is a matter which I think should be investigated by the Government. If this practice is allowed to go unchecked, the people will suffer. So I hope a Commission of Inquiry will be instituted to look into the real position.

    That, briefly, is all, Mr Speaker. I hope I will get a satisfactory explanation.

    Mr Wong Soon Fong (Toa Payoh)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding the effects of acquisition of land by the Government, I wish to draw the attention of the Government to the following points.

    The first is about the question of rental of land which is requisitioned by the Government. When the land is taken over by the Government, the rental of the land is increased. In some cases, it is increased by 100 per cent, and in a certain case a $2-rental has been increased to $20. Attap-dwellers are very poor, and it is not proper to increase land rentals once the land is bought by the Government. I want to cite two examples.

    In Lim Chu Kang and in certain areas like Toa Payoh, after the land has been bought by the Government, the land rental is increased. After the land has been requisitioned by the Government, the livelihood of the people there is affected adversely because of the increase of rental. Therefore, I hope the Government will consider the livelihood of the rural people, especially the attap-dwellers.

    Another point is that after a piece of land has been requisitioned by the Government it wants to develop it. I believe that after the land in Toa Payoh has been requisitioned, that place is intended to be developed into a satellite town. The people in those areas do not object to this plan in principle, but the Government has not given full consideration to the livelihood of the people living there. The Government has not considered the loss of properties incurred as a result of the development

Column: 2145

of that area. The people in those areas are faced with this problem. Therefore, I hope the Minister concerned will give full consideration to their problems and hear their opinions.

    There are two organisations which can reflect the views of the people. One is the Country People's Association, and the other is the Rural Dwellers' Association. The Government should consider their views because they represent the people living in the rural areas. Therefore, I hope the Minister concerned will pay close attention to their views.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Tan Kia Gan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. is a realistic Government, hence it cannot simply accept the suggestion by the hon. Member for Geylang Serai that the Government should buy up the land at Geylang Serai and then allocate it to the existing squatters. To do so, Sir, would just mean the transfer of public funds into the pockets of wealthy land-owners, in this case Alsagoff. There will be a hue and cry from the squatters too, as we are ,now experiencing in Toa Payoh where the tenants have for years paid little or no rent, because the landowners were not able to collect them. Now that it is under proper public administration, those who are asked to pay rent according to the area occupied have expressed dissatisfaction. The Barisan Sosialis politicians have tried to make political capital out of this situation by fomenting trouble because the Government is doing its duty of administering public property in a proper manner.

    After balancing all factors which include taking into account the existing squatters' conditions, Government will only purchase land if there is a bigger proportion available for resettlement purposes than for existing squatters. Resettlement has quite a different objective from that of buying land from private owners and giving it to existing settlers.

    Sir, on the subject of resettlement, the Member for Choa Chu Kang, as well as the Member for Toa Payoh, has

Column: 2146

made allegations about the rates of compensation. The Member for Choa Chu Kang especially has made allegations that the rates of compensation have not been amended but have remained the same since 1957. Sir, I must point out that he has his facts wrong. The rates were amended on many occasions as and when the resettlement department gathered more experience and adapted the needs to suit the circumstances that confronted the department. Members will note that on page 9 of the Report of the Land Clearance and Resettlement Party, there is an amendment slip which amends the existing Scheme "C" to provide for house owners and sub-tenants. This amendment was introduced on 1st December, 1960. There is also a further amendment slip attached to page 15 where the whole original scheme recommended was deleted and replaced by a cyclostyled sheet.

3.00 p.m.

    Items as amended are indicated in the footnote of page 2 of this sheet and the date of the amendment for item (g) is 8th October, 1959, and item (h) in July 1960. I am also to say that a special scheme has been devised to give an additional house exchange alternative to apply particularly to house owners in the Toa Payoh area. Sir, in this case, the Housing Board has bought a piece of land in Kim Keat Road adjacent to the Toa Payoh area, whereby the Housing Board will be erecting houses for the purpose of exchanging with those families who are not farmers in the Toa Payoh area. Sir, to say that this resettlement scheme had been the same ever since it was introduced in 1957 is, therefore, wrong, and indeed, intended to mislead.

    Sir, the Member for Choa Chu Kang also suggested that the development projects were held up because of resettlement difficulties. I quite agree with him, Sir. I can point a finger at the Barisan Sosialis for making things that way. While rendering lip service in support of the Government's development plan for the general good of the vast majority of the people, the Barisan

Column: 2147

Sosialis have gone out of their way to foment trouble among those affected by resettlement in order to stir up the resistance of the settlers. They have tried to obstruct and frustrate Government's development plans by telling the settlers that they should not move out but should make demands for more compensation. In this way, the resettlement problems stagnate into long long drawn out negotiations and thus development projects are being delayed.

    For instance, the Member for Choa Chu Kang now demands that attap-huts should be compensated at $3 per square foot as against the present $1 per square foot, which has been acceptable for thousands of cases. Sir, I would like the House to note the tactics adopted by those people who oppose the Government. For instance, the Member for Toa Payoh, whilst he was in the P.A.P., suggested that one-fifth should be a reasonable sum, but he did not press for it. Now, of course, the Barisan pays $3 per square foot, which is three times that of the rate the Government pays. Then there were suggestions made by the representatives of the Rural Residents Association. This Association suggested $2.30. There is another association, called the Country People's Association, which demands $2.50. These are the tactics which are used by people who are opposing the Government now to raise fantastic demands so that the development projects could be delayed by their agitation.

    Sir, we can see that there is no sincerity in all these proposals to solve the squatter problems. What these people want is to play to the gallery and to demonstrate to the farmers how clever, or shall I say, how unreasonable they are in that they can make so many demands. But the farmers are mostly responsible citizens. I am told that in Toa Payoh now, where the first stage of development is going to take place, out of the 19 families, several of these families have already moved out on their own, accepting the scheme that is offered by the Government.

Column: 2148



    Sir, in the Bulim area, for instance, this subject was brought up by the Member for Choa Chu Kang. In this estate there are more than 200 acres of land acquired by the Government for resettlement purposes. On this land, there are 20 to 30 genuine settlers who have been there for some time. Some of them have cultivated small plots, and others have, without authority, extended their cultivation to cover large tracts of land after the Government has acquired the land. When it was known that Government was taking over, people from neighbouring areas encroached on this resettlement area and illegally moved into it. There are thus two categories of people, and not just one category, as the Member for Choa Chu Kang would like us to believe. Some of these cases of encroachment have been most vociferous and, through the Rural Residents Association, have demanded that they should be compensated at fantastic rates or given large plots of land for themselves. I have personally looked into this matter, and I am satisfied that where the settlers are genuine cases, and not those opportunists who tried to encroach, a sufficient plot of land, depending on fertility but up to two acres each, will be permitted to the existing farmers. The remainder of the land will be divided into lots for resettlement purposes. Those who are not farmers but who have huts and have actually been living there for some time will be allowed to retain their huts with their surrounding land area, between 6,000 and 8,000 square feet, these are fair adjustments.

    Sir, the Member for Choa Chu Kang was talking absolute rubbish when he tried to make out a case of legality. If the squatters had any legal status, the Government would be prepared to purchase their land from them. It is because they have no legal status and because the Government is generous enough not to go through the normal process of law that the present scheme for ex-gratia payment of compensation has been devised. In the case of Bulim Estate, Sir, the genuine farmers will, be

Column: 2149

allotted their farm lots and the genuine non-farmers will be allotted their house lots as stated above.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I just wish to add a few words to what the Minister for National Development has said. It is his Ministry that is primarily responsible for resettlement and rehousing. My Ministry, which includes the Land Office, is primarily concerned with the purchase and acquisition of land for public purposes.

    First, the Master Plan. Sir, I do not expect the Master Plan, and the complete revision of it, to be completed anywhere before the next 15 months. It is a matter of some importance, when an exercise of so far-reaching a nature is being conducted, that not only must all interests be carefully balanced, but also that the full implications of the competition between the high density demanded by the Housing Board and more land demanded by the Finance Ministry's Economic Development Division, should be weighed against the long-term interest of reasonable planning in an over-crowded island like Singapore. Members will recall that there was a question of who the Chief Planner is to be. It is because some considerable importance is attached to the duties of the Chief Planner, who will have to help complete the revision of the Master Plan, that I say it is not likely to be completed at an early date. First we have to find somebody who is not only theoretically qualified as a Planner of competence, but who has had experience of tropical architectural conditions. What I can assure the Member for Tanglin is that nobody is being held up in the present development because of the Master Plan. The Master Plan is there. From time to time minor adjustments and amendments are being made to it to fit in with industrial development and other housing development. But to give the Member an instance. A revision was made to the Tanjong Rhu industrial site, a belt that runs somewhere from the Singapore Swimming Club right up to the end of Tanjong Rhu. Because of the slowness of development in the Jurong site in

Column: 2150

laying out water and electricity services, we decided that here was an area which could assist in the immediate demand for suitable industrial sites with a water frontage. The planners were satisfied. So were the Land Oflice. And the land is now being reclassified for industrial uses. At the same time, because Kallang Park has proved to be a little bit of a white elephant, because there is not such a density of population to justify a large and barren park-land, readjustments have been made to allow part of Kallang Park to be used as a housing estate by the Housing and Development Board. The reasons are obvious. The uses of Kallang Park have been watched and scrutinised over the last two and a half years. For reasons not only because there is no density of population in the area but also because of transport conditions, the park is not used in the way it was hoped it would be used. Therefore, one sector amounting to about 35 per cent of the land bordering Mountbatten Road at the Nicoll Highway side is being test-bored at the moment to find out whether it is suitable for housing development. If it is, one sector will be set aside for housing, and that will provide the density of population for the use of the rest of Kallang Park. So it is a constant process of adjustments. If any developer wants to use a piece of land; if he thinks the Master Plan is not what it should be because he has adequate reasons why it should be altered, then his proposal for reconsideration will receive sympathetic and new scrutiny. There is nobody who is in any way being penalised as a result of our not, so to speak, republishing once and for all an amended Master Plan. There is no end to planning.

3.15 p.m.

    Planning is to fit in with human needs. Planning has to fit in with conditions which alter from time to time. Of course, there are certain basic principles which one observes in planning, because they are of some relevance. As I have stated, we are looking for a competent Chief Planner.

Column: 2151



    Sir, I think the Member for Hong Lim is the person least qualified to cry on behalf of the farmers and the poor squatters. He is always crying on behalf of somebody, Sir. The trouble is that when we entrusted him with the responsibility of doing these things -

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: On a point of clarification, Sir.

    The Prime Minister resumed his seat.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, when I was the Minister in charge of land problems, I remember discussing with the Prime Minister one day about trying to carry out a programme, the principles of which I have enunciated just now. I met with the same opposition as I met with in the building of houses and other things.

    The Prime Minister: It is a strange thing! Thank God the Chairman of the Housing Development Board does not seem to meet with any opposition in putting up houses at the rate of about 10,000 units a year; something which even the Member for Hong Lim, in his healthier days as the Minister for National Development, was unable to do.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the rate of progress on the building of S.I.T. flats commenced only after the Hong Lim by-election. It should be pointed out that during the Hong Lim by-election certain Ministers spoke on the platform that the rents of the flats were expensive because the flats were built on plans laid down by the ex-Minister for National Development, which was an admission that the plans and the organisation were laid down by the ex-Minister for National Development.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, he cannot have it both ways. Either he had no opposition, and plans and development were all prepared and all he needed was to press the button and the houses would spring up; or he did meet with opposition, in which case that was why the houses did not go up. I suggest to

Column: 2152

him that the reason why nothing happened was that he went on a witch-hunt, and everybody was either a dangerous stooge, a spy or a reactionary, and the result was that he landed himself with a group of weak and sycophantic officials who were unable to put the buildings up. It is as simple as that. As for this land -

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: On a point of -

    The Prime Minister: May I just finish this? This business about the farmers; there was no alteration. We said, here was the Land Office; here was the P.A.P. Five-Year Plan on land for farmers, drafted with considerable care by the Minister for Health and Law. In our minds we have certain patterns as to how we could, without in fact confiscating and expropriating the land of the landlords, compel the use of the land by farmers at cheap rates and give them security of tenure. It is all on the record. If we were to publish the draft Bill that he produced on his own without consultation -

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: On a point of clarification, Sir.

    The Chairman: Order.

    The Prime Minister: The Member will be given full opportunity to reply. These are things on the record. All we had was a Bill. Nobody can knock a nail down without the Minister first saying yes. Nobody can go from A to B or do anything without the Minister first saying yes. The Member's theory of planning is that the Minister is omniscient, omnipresent, omnipotent. Yes. No. Thou shall do this. Thou shall not do that. And it is all the Minister.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Omnivorous!

    The Prime Minister: Sir, we put up a practical Bill which we withdrew because, as I explained to the House, there was the problem of those tenants. They are not tenants and they are not squatters. They are licensees. They collect fish and eggs on land belonging to other people who collect rubber and

Column: 2153

coconuts. We did not know how to resolve that problem. We had three possible alternatives. I gave my former Parliamentary Secretary, the Member for Upper Serangoon, and the Member for Choa Chu Kang the honourable task of calling up the farmers, arranging meetings, and getting together to try and resolve it. The very fact - [Interruption]. Well, that is the tragedy, Sir. They can only say, why not accept the Country People's Association's proposals? The Member for Toa Payoh and the Member for Choa Chu Kang told me, "What shall we do about this Country People's Association? There are a lot of Communists inside. They are taking advantage of us. We get a standpipe put up and they claim the credit for it. What shall we do?" These are facts. We discussed this ad infinitum, time and time again -

    Mr Ong Chang Sam rose -

    The Chairman: On a point of order?

    Mr Ong Chang Sam: On a point of clarification.

    The Prime Minister: Surely.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Just now the Prime Minister has alleged that I told him that there were some people in the Rural People's Association and the Rural Dwellers' Association who were Communists. This is not correct. After the Select Committee meeting at that time I discussed with the Prime Minister about how to invite the representatives of the two rural organisations to take part in discussing this problem. They had suggested convening a meeting. At that time, Mr Speaker, Sir, you were the Chairman of the Select Committee discussing the Agricultural Leases Bill. The crux of the whole problem was that I only said that the representatives of these organisations should be invited to discuss this matter. The Prime Minister talked with me as how to solve this problem. I told him it was better to wait until the by-election was over. I did not say there were Communists in these two organisations -

Column: 2154



    Mr Ong Eng Guan rose -

    The Chairman: The Prime Minister has not given way to the Member for Hong Lim yet.

    The Prime Minister: There should be one at a time. I am pleased to know that after my absence of three days I am able to arouse so much interest generally! In the process of this investigation into the Chinese school students and the parents whom they rustled up to attend the Chinese High School Parents' Day on Sunday, this particular point, as to whether the Member for Choa Chu Kang said that, could be covered. I am prepared to say this on oath, give evidence and the date. If he denies it and there is evidence to justify it, then he will have to take the consequences -

    Mr Ong Chang Sam rose -

    The Chairman: On a point of order?

    Mr Ong Chang Sam: On a point of clarification, Sir.

    The Prime Minister: Surely.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister has been talking about something entirely different. He has alleged that I said there were Communists in the two rural organisations. But when he stood up to reply, he talked about the parents of the Chinese school students. That is entirely irrelevant.
